awd_titl_txt: Living Growth Synthesis of Metal Oxide Nanocrystals: Toward Enhanced Control of Composition, Size and Uniformity
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanocrystals, very small crystals with sizes on the order of 0.000001 millimeters (equal in size to 5-10 atoms), have interesting properties that can lead to novel chemistry. Metal oxide nanocrystals, the subject of this study, are promising next-generation materials for use as catalysts, energy storage materials, electronic device components, sensors, and diagnostic probes.  Chemists need better ways to control the composition and structure of the nanocrystals at the atomic level in order to be able to harness the properties of these new materials. Dr. Hutchison is developing a new synthesis approach that grows nanocrystals in a highly controlled manner by the continuous, sequential addition of metal and oxygen atoms to the surface of a nanocrystal. Such a continuous growth process, referred to as "living growth", attaches atoms to the nanocrystals with high precision, permitting simultaneous control of size, uniformity, and composition.  All of these properties are important for specific potential applications. The researchers are developing general approaches to the production of new nanomaterials to be used in industry as thin film, magnetic materials, and catalysts. Dr. Hutchison's research attracts a diverse, interdisciplinary group of undergraduate and graduate students, including underrepresented minorities. In addition to their scientific training, students develop and implement written professional development plans and receive training on innovation and entrepreneurship so that they can enhance the societal impact of their research. The results of the research are shared with the general public through the regional meetings.  The students interact with scientists from industry at nanomaterial workshops offered at the University of Oregon's Center for Advanced Materials Characterization. 

In this research program, Dr. Hutchison of the University of Oregon is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program to investigate "living growth" syntheses of inorganic nanocrystals with the aim of gaining simultaneous control of core diameter and uniformity, core composition, doping levels and core-shell structures.  Living growth synthesis works in much the same way that living polymerization yields polymers with controlled molecular weight, copolymer composition and block copolymer structures.  Dr. Hutchison produces mixed metal oxide nanocrystals that have been difficult to synthesize by thermal decomposition or other high temperature methods. The research has established a general approach to producing new metal oxides with controlled atomic-level composition and size.  The project builds fundamental understanding of the reactions producing these nanocrystals and supports new applications in thin film, magnetic and catalysis research. Dr. Hutchison actively engages a diverse team of undergraduate and graduate students in his research and augments their research training with targeted professional development activities such as training on innovation and entrepreneurship. The results of the research are disseminated through scientific publication, the regional meetings, graduate courses, and industry workshops.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The project forged a new approach to the controlled growth of metal oxide nanocrystals through the slow, continuous addition of metal complexes to the nanocrystal surface.  Compared to more conventional growth methods, this approach permitted a systematic study of the role of the precursor structure, precursor addition rate, reaction temperature, and the reaction atmosphere.  The practical benefit of the approach is that it makes it possible to synthesize previously inaccessible nanocrystal compositions and structures that are useful in applications, such as in plasmonic and magnetic materials.

The primary outcomes of the research include: (1) The development of a general, practical synthesis for several types of metal oxide nanocrystals in which the diameter can be systematically controlled at the atomic level.  The level of control demonstrated is equivalent to adding single layers of atoms at a time. (2) The ability to predictably and reliably place a second type of metal atom (a dopant) into a matrix of the main metal oxide.  Using this method, dopant metal ions could be placed uniformly throughout the nanocrystal matrix, or deliberately concentrated at desirable locations within the nanocrystal, for example within the core or on the surface.  (3) The control of size and dopant placement within nanocrystals to produce new materials with tunable optical or magnetic properties.  These materials helped establish the interrelationship between the optical or magnetic properties and the size, structure and composition for the nanocrystals.  (4) A deeper understanding of the role that the surface reactivity of the nanocrystal plays in the growth process.  We found that the composition (and therefore reactivity) of the surface, along with the flux of precursor to the surface, strongly influenced the nanocrystal growth process.

The broader impacts of the education and training aspects of this project include: (1) The development of a new course graduate-level course, Nanomaterials Design, Structure and Characterization. (2) A focus on student training and career acceleration through the development of comprehensive career planning and practical skills training to complement research training.  Six graduate and two undergraduate researchers participated in these trainings.  Half of these students were women and/or underrepresented minorities in STEM. (3) The development of innovation training to enhance the positive impact of scientific discoveries for society.  Throughout the project we collaborated with the business school to develop a curriculum for scientists and engineers to learn about the innovation process so that they are prepared to translate discoveries to the market for societal benefit.


Last Modified: 11/29/2021
Modified by: James E Hutchison
